citation.article-title: Desulfonatronum lacustre gen. nov., sp. nov.: a new alkaliphilic sulfate-reducing bacterium utilizing ethanol.

p.s: Description of Desulfonatronum laeustre sp. nov.
Desulfonatronum laeustre (laeustre, of laeus, lake).
A motile vibrio with a single polar flagellum.
Cells measure 0.7-0.9 x 2-3 μm and occur singly or in pairs; under suboptimal conditions, they look like spirilla.
Multiplication occurs by binary fission.
Cell wall structure is of the gram-negative type.
Strictly anaerobic, chemolithotrophic.
Utilizes only hydrogen, formate, or ethanol as electron donors and sulfate, sulfite, or thiosulfate as electron acceptors.
Acetate is produced from ethanol.
Sulfide is the only product of catabolic reduction of sulfur compounds.
Yeast extract or acetate are utilized for anabolism.
Obligate alkaliphile that does not grow at pH below 8; the upper limit is pH 10; the optimum is pH 9.5.
Obligately depends on carbonate and sodium ions.
NaCl is not required.
Up to 10% NaCl can be tolerated.
Mesophile.
Optimal temperature is 37-40°C, the limits are 20 and 45°C.
The G+C content of DNA is 57.3 mol % (thermal denaturation method).
The habitat is bottom sediments of alkaline athalassic lakes.
The type strain Z-7951T was isolated from sediments in a lagoon of Lake Khadyn, Tuva.2 The type strain was deposited with the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen as DSM 10312.
